body.p:
Louisville
Corner of 12 and Walnut
Jany 24, 1863
To his Excellency G. F Robinson
Governor of Ky.
I have an indictment prefered against me and am fined 20 Dollars and costs I have borrowed 10 and paid it into Court. I cannot possibly get the remaining sum

I have a Widowed and afflicted sister and her 3 children depending upon me for support -- I have no means to keep them only by serving which is sometimes difficult to get
We are very often without the common necessaries of life or a fire to warm us. I have no Furniture and scarcely 10 Dollars worth of goods in my little store
I am a lone Women and very delicate in health
I am threatened to be incarcerated if I cannot pay this money, if such takes place my sister as well as her children and myself must become a burthen upon the Commonwealth of Ky.
This is the first offense I am quite ignorant of the Laws of this country.

I have only been in this Country 12 months
Trusting you will listen to this humble appeal
I am your most obedieous Petitioner Mary Ann Burns

To his Excelency J. F. Robinson
Governor of Ky
I corroborate the statements of the within Petitioner

W R Hydes Marshal city of Louisville Ky
Phil Tomppert Jr. C C C L
The Petitioner being poor, as stated in her petition & considering her case somewhat deserving Executive clemency I respectfully ask for a respite for six months

W, G, Reasor, atto
I concur with Mr Reasor
Geo. W. Johnston

Mary Ann Burns
Pettn to remit fine
Louisville City Ct
Respite fine 6 months
J F Robinson
$20. } --
M. A. Burns
Issd Feby 9. 1863
